stem: The nurse is analyzing clinical communication during a hand-off report. For each statement, select whether it demonstrates Inclusive/Unbiased Communication or Biased/Non-Professional Communication.

rows.text: The client in Room 4 is a 'frequent flier' here for their usual drug-seeking behavior.
The client is 48 hours post-op and identifies as non-binary; they prefer 'they/them' pronouns.
This client has difficulty following the plan because they are 'culturally' resistant to medicine.
The client has a history of Substance Use Disorder (SUD) and is currently reporting an 8/10 pain level.

rationale.correct: Biased language in clinical hand-offs negatively impacts patient safety. (r1) Terms like 'frequent flier' and 'drug-seeking' are stigmatizing and clinically imprecise. (r2) Correct use of pronouns and gender identity is inclusive and legal standard. (r3) Stereotyping a client as 'culturally resistant' is a sign of implicit bias. (r4) Using medical terminology ('SUD') rather than stigmatizing labels ('addict') is professional and objective.
rationale.incorrect: Inclusive communication focuses on person-first language and objective clinical facts rather than moral judgment.
clinicalPearls: Stigmatizing language in nursing charts is associated with lower quality of care and increased medical errors.

questionTrap.trap: The 'Telling it like it is' Fallacy
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that 'slang' or 'clinical nicknames' (Frequent flier, druggie, non-compliant) are always considered a bias violation in NGN questions. Stick to person-first, objective language.

mnemonic.title: P-O-L-I-T-E
mnemonic.expansion: Person-first, Objective, Label-free, Inclusive, Truthful, Empathetic.

reviewUnits.heading: Unbiased Clinical Communication
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must recognize that language shapes care. Using stigmatizing labels Leads to diagnostic overshadowing, where real medical problems are ignored due to the clinician's negative perception of the patient.
